author: Patrick Lion
title: Pupils pay tribute to 'inspiring' primary school headteacher and former Come Dine With Me contestant who died suddenly
text:
Pupils pay tribute to 'inspiring' primary school headteacher and former Come Dine With Me contestant who died suddenly The body of 51-year-old Huw Jones, head of Albert Primary School in Penarth, was discovered on Wednesday Share Primary school headteacher Huw Jones, as he appeared on Come Dine With Me in 2011, has been found dead in Wales Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Students and friends have paid tribute to an "inspiring" headteacher and former Come Dine With Me contestant who died suddenly. 
The body of Huw Jones, head of Albert Primary School in Penarth, Wales, was discovered on Wednesday. 
Tributes to the head teacher thanked him for inspiring pupils in drama and said the 51-year-old was very popular. 
His death comes just days after Albert Primary School received a "green rating" - the highest - in the Welsh Government's banding system. Huw Jones on a swing at the school (Photo: South Wales Echo) 
Mr Jones appeared on a special Shrove Tuesday edition of Channel 4 programme Come Dine With Me in 2011. 
A description of his appearance said: "Sadly Huw plans mushroom tart, while events manager Stewart has a mushroom phobia." 
The show, which shows Mr Jones tossing pancakes, was repeated many times. 
One parent, who did not want to be named told Penarth Times : “This is a terrible tragedy. 
"He was such a good sport and even went on Come Dine with Me. 
"He was one of those heads you could easily talk to. 
“Mr Jones has been at this school for about 12 years and is very popular. He has been under a lot of pressure like a lot of heads these days. 
“We feel so sorry for his family.” 
The local council emailed parents of children today to inform them of Mr Jones' death, and said counselling would be available for children and staff, Wales Online reports. Albert Primary School, Penarth (Photo: South Wales Echo) 
It said: “It is with deep sadness that I have to inform you that on February 1 South Wales Police found a body they believe to be that of Huw Jones, Albert Road Primary’s head teacher. 
“The school will remain open today and staff will be on site. 
“Our intention is to tell pupils once we have formal confirmation of this sad news. 
“However, if you wish to take your child out of school today you will be able to do so at any time. 
“A counselling service will be made available to all pupils and staff within the school." Read More Student found dead in gorge is 'fourth suicide' at same top university since start of academic year 
One shocked parent wrote on Facebook: "Can't believe this is the kids' head teacher!" 
One student said on Facebook: "Mr Jones was such an exciting new headteacher for everyone at Albert primary... he brought out my inner dramatic side completely and really helped me discover my love for performing at such a young age. 
"Woke up to the saddest news, rest in peace Huw, you were an inspiration to many xx." 
A friend wrote: "Goodbye my friend. May you light up the sky like the bright bright star that you always were. 
"I'll miss you very much. You'll always be in my heart." 
Mr Jones described himself on social media as a "headteacher who believes that creativity is the core of what education is about." 
He added: "One can hope that there will come a time where politicians will not meddle!" 
The 406-pupil school was rated excellent by inspectors last year. 
Mr Jones competed in his first London Marathon in 2010 in a bid to raise money for a diabetes charity after being inspired by a colleague's daughter. 
However, his social media presence shows he has also competed in the event in subsequent years. Read More Vet dubbed 'beautiful slaughterer' euthanised herself with drug she used to put animals down 
A spokesman for the Vale of Glamorgan council said: “On February 1 South Wales Police informed the council that they had found a body they believe to be that of Huw Jones, Albert Primary School’s head teacher. 
“We have informed staff, parents, and pupils of this sad news today. A counselling service is being made available to provide any support that is required.” 
A spokesman for South Wales Police said: “We are investigating the sudden death of a 51-year-old man, whose body was discovered in Fort Road, Lavernock, on Wednesday, February 1. 
“The man’s next of kin has been informed and a file of evidence is being prepared for HM Coroner.”
